title: Late goals are destroying Liverpool's season and solution isn't obvious
description: Why have Liverpool gone from mentality monsters to a side there for the taking?
fullText:
It was early in the season that Liverpool supporters noticed a subtle change at the club's training ground.

And with each game that passed, the collection of images grew. First there is a picture of Federico Chiesa celebrating his 88th-minute goal against Bournemouth on the opening day of the Premier League season, a goal that put Liverpool back into the lead after the Cherries had come back from 2-0 down to draw level. Mohamed Salah would score in stoppage time to put the result beyond doubt.

Next to it was placed an image of teenager Rio Ngumoha scoring a dramatic winner in the 100th minute at St James' Park as Newcastle were beaten 3-2. A week later and Dominik Szoboszlai scored a free-kick in the 83rd minute against Arsenal, and the following weekend Salah scored a 95th-minute penalty at Burnley - a pair of back-to-back 1-0 wins, two more photos on the wall.

After five games, Liverpool had 15 points on the board and a whole set of images for the players to take inspiration from. The Reds were top of the league with a 100% record and favourites to retain their title.

Throw in a 92nd-minute winner against Atletico Madrid in the Champions League - another game in which Liverpool had surrendered a two-goal lead - and from the outside at least, things were looking good for Arne Slot's side. The Dutchman put his side's knack of winning games with late goals down to self-belief and fitness.

But the cracks were showing in the goals his team were conceding and now, five months on, there are precious few new images to line the walls of Liverpool's training ground.

The Reds' habit of scoring late winners has turned on its head, and it is they who are finding themselves conceding late on. Liverpool are now there for the taking.

In Liverpool's three league games that followed their golden start, they faced Crystal Palace, Chelsea and Manchester United and conceded winning goals in the 84th minute or later each time.

And when Erling Haaland dispatched his injury-time penalty at Anfield on Sunday, it was the fourth time that Liverpool had conceded an injury-time winner in the league this season. No team in a single Premier League campaign has ever conceded more.

Only three teams (Burnley, Leeds and Newcastle) have conceded more goals in the final 10 minutes plus injury time of games than Liverpool (10) this season and no team has lost more points than Liverpool (eight) from those goals.

Those eight points would put them level with Aston Villa in third, but instead Liverpool find themselves in sixth and four points behind Chelsea, who are fifth.

On occasions this season, Virgil van Dijk has used the word "sloppy" to describe Liverpool's struggles.

After a 1-1 draw against Burnley in January, the Liverpool captain said: "After 60 minutes, we started to become sloppy and it's not the first time. We have to address that."

A few days later in Milan, that quote was put to left-back Milos Kerkez, who told BBC Sport that he agreed with Van Dijk's assessment.

"After 60-70 [minutes] we always lose focus and lose some tactical discipline. I don't know, we get tired, I am not sure whatever it is, but I agree with that."

One of the big reasons Slot was brought in to succeed Jurgen Klopp was his impressive ability to keep his players fit. Of the shortlisted managers, only Ruben Amorim boasted a better record.

The Dutchman opted for a style of training that was less intense than what players may have been used to.

Slot had worked at Feyenoord with Ruben Peeters who followed him to Liverpool as the first team's lead performance coach. The pair tailored training to specific players, altering the intensity based on Liverpool's schedule and demands of upcoming games.

Sessions became longer but less intense and, on match days, Slot's Liverpool played less intensely out of possession than Klopp's teams did.

All of these factors, built upon a squad that was conditioned to play under Klopp, combined to leave them remarkably injury-free last season, resulting in Liverpool being crowned Premier League champions.

They have not been so fortunate this season.

Liverpool have looked to break teams down by initially committing bodies to the box, an approach that has left them vulnerable to counter-attacks.

Teams have deliberately looked to play long against Liverpool, which has also introduced more end-to-end running and duelling. The Liverpool players have physically struggled with this.

Slot has since gone for a more measured and defensively solid set-up which has reduced how end-to-end games are, but Liverpool struggle to score early.

The Premier League is home to the most sprints and high-intensity runs in Europe. Opponents can afford to minimise how much they run through a season by spending large parts of the game in their pragmatic low blocks.

However, Liverpool's fans are likely to want to see high-octane games from their side.

With an uptick in soft tissue injuries, there is a worry the training methods and on-field tactics described here have been sub-optimal this season when compared to last season, with Liverpool's players dropping off in the latter parts of games.

Between wanting to appease fans, ensuring his players stay fit, wanting to score early and aiming to stay solid at the back, the Liverpool boss has a difficult balancing act on his hands.

When Van Dijk spoke again on Sunday, the response was telling. Liverpool can't put a pin on it. As Slot repeatedly says, it's always a "different goal".

This time, the cause was one of Liverpool's most experienced players, goalkeeper Alisson, making a mistake as he fouled Matheus Nunes.

"I think you can't compare all of the goals. I think maybe you can compare the Palace goal and the Bournemouth goal, but this one you can't compare with the others. But the fact is that we conceded that late on and I keep saying it but we have to do better in this," said Van Dijk.

Asked if Liverpool were guilty of being sloppy again, Van Dijk added: "I don't know in this moment. It's difficult for me to say that. I don't have the whole game completely in front of me right now so it's something we will discuss [on Monday]."

Given Liverpool's injury crisis, the lack of depth on the bench is playing a part too. Manchester City were able to bring on Rayan Cherki who influenced the dynamic of Pep Guardiola's attack, while Slot's first substitution was Curtis Jones for Cody Gakpo in the 85th minute, before throwing on Chiesa in injury-time.

And that is precisely where Liverpool are at right now. A side aware of their cracks but unable to paper over them, never mind fix them.

Until Sunday, the Reds were unbeaten in 109 home league games when scoring the opening goal (W98 D11). It was the latest they have ever led in a Premier League game yet gone on to lose, with Bernardo Silva's 84th-minute equaliser followed by Haaland's late penalty.

The reality is that Szoboszlai's stunning free-kick for the opening goal on Sunday should be another image on that wall in Kirkby. In the end, it was worth nothing as Liverpool again failed to see the game out.

In Premier League history, no team has ever scored more injury-time winners than Liverpool. They stand clear with 47, ahead of Arsenal (36) and Manchester United (34).

Liverpool have been renowned for late drama across their illustrious history. Yet in the here and now, they're making the wrong kind of history.

As Slot said on Sunday: "We are getting almost used to conceding a goal in extra time."

'Killjoy' - did VAR get late drama in Liverpool v Man City right?

Man City fight back for dramatic late win at Liverpool

title: ‚ÄòWas I scared going back to China? No‚Äô: Ai Weiwei on AI, western censorship and returning home
description:
He has been jailed, tracked and threatened by China‚Äôs government. What was it like pay a visit home? As he publishes a polemic about surveillance and state control, the artist relives a momentous trip to see his mother
Ai Weiwei is talking me through the decision-making process before his first visit to China in over a decade. The artist, known around the world as the most famous critic of the Chinese communist regime, had to do some fraught arithmetic before deciding to head back home.
Before boarding a flight with his son, who had never met the artist‚Äôs elderly mother, Ai thought back to his time in detention when his captors told him he would spend the next 13 years in custody on bogus charges: ‚ÄúThey said, ‚ÄòWhen you come out, your son won‚Äôt recognise you.
fullText:
He has been jailed, tracked and threatened by China‚Äôs government. What was it like pay a visit home? As he publishes a polemic about surveillance and state control, the artist relives a momentous trip to see his mother

Ai Weiwei is talking me through the decision-making process before his first visit to China in over a decade. The artist, known around the world as the most famous critic of the Chinese communist regime, had to do some fraught arithmetic before deciding to head back home.

Before boarding a flight with his son, who had never met the artist‚Äôs elderly mother, Ai thought back to his time in detention when his captors told him he would spend the next 13 years in custody on bogus charges: ‚ÄúThey said, ‚ÄòWhen you come out, your son won‚Äôt recognise you.‚Äô That was very heavy and really the only moment that touched me.‚Äù

He ended up spending several months in captivity. Lao, his son, is now 17. Ai says Lao doesn‚Äôt really need his guidance any more so he decided to book their flights and roll the dice. ‚ÄúPeople said, ‚ÄòAre you scared?‚Äô I said, ‚ÄòNo, why should I be scared?‚Äô I‚Äôm Chinese. I have a Chinese passport. I‚Äôm entitled to go back and see my mum. So I went back.‚Äù

Welcome to the life of Ai Weiwei. For most people, returning home doesn‚Äôt involve weighing up the risk of whether you‚Äôll see close family ever again, but that‚Äôs the reality for a 68-year-old whose whole existence has been shaped by authoritarianism and the struggle against it.

His trip to China went well. He ended up being interviewed at the airport and released after a couple of hours into a country whose smells, sights and sounds were soothing to him. Ai described the journey as being like ‚Äúa phone call suddenly reconnecting‚Äù. Today, he‚Äôs more poetic, describing it as ‚Äúa piece of jade broken that you can put back together because it matches very well. Everything‚Äôs so familiar: the light, the temperature, the people.‚Äù

Ai is meeting me in the London offices of his publisher to talk about his new book, On Censorship, a 90-page polemic on the nature of state control, AI and surveillance. The man certainly knows about these things. Born in Beijing in 1957, he grew up in labour camps in north-west China following the exile of his father, the poet Ai Qing. In 2011, he was detained for 81 days in a 170 sq ft windowless prison because of his own activism. Upon his release, he was tracked, interrogated and threatened by the Chinese state; then his passport was returned in 2015 and he began a life in exile. He currently divides his time between Lisbon, Berlin and Cambridge.

His artworks are as dramatic as his backstory. An army of 1,600 Chinese artisans created 100m hand-painted porcelain ‚Äúseeds‚Äù that were scattered over the floor of Tate Modern‚Äôs Turbine Hall in London 16 years ago. He cloaked Berlin‚Äôs Konzerthaus in 14,000 fluorescent orange lifejackets worn by refugees; and made a film dedicated to the children who died in the 2008 Sichuan earthquake. That direct challenge to the official state narrative made him ‚Äúthe most dangerous person in China‚Äù.

His upcoming work, at Aviva Studios in Manchester, involves 30 tonnes of buttons, which were saved from a London factory that was closing down and smuggled into China to be turned into huge hanging artworks by craftspeople.

The book is a startling read, arguing that those in the west misunderstand the nature of censorship. He defines it as ‚Äúthe exercise of power over intellectual space‚Äù, both ‚Äúan indispensable tool of mental enslavement and a fundamental source of political corruption‚Äù. It is not just authoritarian regimes, he warns. Liberal societies think that censorship is rare, ‚Äúbut people forget that even on sunny days, shadows are inevitable‚Äù.

Some of the arguments are perplexing. In a section about the limitations of AI, the artist refers to the selfie he took with AfD leader Alice Weidel in 2018. He says AI decided that the image, which is real, must have been fake because the pair seemed to be on opposite ends of the political spectrum. At the time of the selfie, Weidel, whose grandfather was a Nazi, was considered to be in the more moderate wing of the far-right party, but since becoming leader has called for ‚Äúlarge-scale repatriations‚Äù of foreigners, saying the country‚Äôs focus on the Holocaust is akin to a ‚Äúguilt cult‚Äù.

Does Ai regret the selfie? He tells me that on many issues, her political demands ‚Äúcould be wrong‚Äù, but she‚Äôs still ‚Äúmore rational than other political opponents in Germany‚Äù. What about her anti-immigrant rhetoric ‚Äì isn‚Äôt that anathema to him? ‚ÄúSome states don‚Äôt even accept one [immigrant] and Germany accepts 1.2 million, which is a pretty generous decision,‚Äù he replies. ‚ÄúSo if they change the policy and they want to limit it, then there is nothing wrong.‚Äù

He‚Äôs also impressed by the fact that Weidel ‚Äúopenly wants Germany to be more independent from American influence‚Äù. He adds: ‚ÄúI think those are some of the things that we need to do.‚Äù Those who know German politics would find that argument surprising because the AfD are seen as the party who are closest to Trump and nearly all parties in the country want more independence from the US. A ringing endorsement of someone at the outermost reaches of far-right European politics might cause a few double takes, and there are more surprises.

Ai‚Äôs attitude to China has shifted dramatically. The nation, he said recently, is ‚Äúin an upward phase,‚Äù pointing to the technological advancements made and increased personal freedoms. The west, however, struggles to ‚Äúsustain its own logic‚Äù, has lost its ‚Äúethical authority‚Äù and has ‚Äúdescended into something barely recognisable‚Äù.

Although a quick glance across the Atlantic at America in the age of ICE raids does somewhat make his point, he means Europe, too. So is the Chinese regime‚Äôs most famous critic now toeing the party line? ‚ÄúMy position with China started before I could recognise myself as an individual. I grew up in this black hole with my father,‚Äù he says, pointing to a picture on his iPhone of a desolate location in north-west China.

He‚Äôs not angry exactly, but the suggestion that he‚Äôs softened on the Chinese government has touched a nerve. ‚ÄúI still have a Chinese passport. My mum is still Chinese. So that‚Äôs my only relationship to China,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not nostalgic. I‚Äôm not patriotic.‚Äù What about the claim that the west embraces censorship? Is that his experience in the UK? ‚ÄúI cannot get into details,‚Äù he says cryptically. ‚ÄúBut I feel the same kind of surveillance, same kind of censorship in the west.‚Äù

Pressed for an example, he tells me a story about the Royal Academy in London, an institution that gave him a landmark exhibition in 2015 and made him an honorary member in 2011 following his detainment in China. In November 2023, an exhibition of new works to be shown at the Lisson Gallery was pulled after he posted a tweet that began: ‚ÄúThe sense of guilt around the persecution of the Jewish people has been, at times, transferred to offset the Arab world.‚Äù The tweet was deleted, with the artist telling journalists his show had ‚Äúeffectively [been] cancelled‚Äù.

In the aftermath, a vote was then held at the RA to determine whether his membership should be revoked because of accusations that the post was antisemitic. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt have the intention of an antisemite. My best friends, they‚Äôre all Jewish people,‚Äù says Ai. ‚ÄúI tweeted millions of tweets on Twitter, but [how is it that] this tweet can cause such trouble? Then they said the procedure is to let the Academicians vote.‚Äù

His peers supported him and he won the vote. Ai was then asked to write an article about freedom of speech for the RA‚Äôs magazine, which he did, arguing: ‚ÄúSpeaking the truth and insisting on one‚Äôs own perspective is dangerous and may come at a heavy price. Books may go unpublished, exhibitions may be closed, concerts cancelled.‚Äù

After he sent it, there was silence. Then he says the RA claimed they didn‚Äôt have room to run the piece. For him, this is the censorship in the west, which he argues in On Censorship can be ‚Äúmore covert, more deceptive and more corrosive‚Äù than in authoritarian regimes. ‚ÄúI have several cases like this,‚Äù Ai adds. ‚ÄúHappens in Britain and in Germany.‚Äù

The RA disputes this account, claiming the decision to drop the piece was made before Ai submitted it. A spokesperson added: ‚ÄúPlurality of voices, tolerance and free thinking are at the core of what we stand for and seek to protect.‚Äù

I wonder how Ai feels about the world in 2026. His new book paints it as a place without refuge for those who value self-expression and freedom of speech. ‚ÄúI think today we are living in a complicated world, where life is more like a shattered mirror,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúIt reflects the reality, but the reality can be a broken reality.‚Äù

Did his trip to China restore his faith in humanity? There‚Äôs a pause. ‚ÄúIf we were in the time of the Tang dynasty, someone like me would go back and write beautiful poetry,‚Äù he says, smiling. ‚ÄúBut not today. I just take a few selfies.‚Äù

title: Files cast light on Jeffrey Epstein‚Äôs ties to cryptocurrency
description:
Newly released documents detail convicted sex offender‚Äôs early backing of bitcoin and Coinbase 
Millions of files related to Jeffrey Epstein have brought to light his ties to the highest echelons of the cryptocurrency industry.
Documents published last week by the US Department of Justice reveal Epstein bankrolled the ‚Äúprincipal home and funding source‚Äù for bitcoin, the world‚Äôs largest cryptocurrency, during its nascent stages; he also invested $3m in Coinbase in 2014, the largest cryptocurrency exchange in the US, and cut a check that same year to Blockstream, a prominent bitcoin-focused technology firm. Both crypto startups accepted Epstein‚Äôs investments in 2014 ‚Äì six years after his 2008 conviction in Florida for soliciting prostitution from a minor.
 Continue reading...
fullText:
Newly released documents detail convicted sex offender‚Äôs early backing of bitcoin and Coinbase

Millions of files related to Jeffrey Epstein have brought to light his ties to the highest echelons of the cryptocurrency industry.

Documents published last week by the US Department of Justice reveal Epstein bankrolled the ‚Äúprincipal home and funding source‚Äù for bitcoin, the world‚Äôs largest cryptocurrency, during its nascent stages; he also invested $3m in Coinbase in 2014, the largest cryptocurrency exchange in the US, and cut a check that same year to Blockstream, a prominent bitcoin-focused technology firm. Both crypto startups accepted Epstein‚Äôs investments in 2014 ‚Äì six years after his 2008 conviction in Florida for soliciting prostitution from a minor.

Despite murmurings among crypto communities online about the need for a sector-level reckoning around the Epstein files‚Äô revelations, most industry players predict few consequences for crypto companies or the sector writ large. Some see Epstein as a ‚Äúskeptical investor‚Äù who pulled out of his crypto investments prematurely; others go so far as to claim Epstein was attempting to ‚Äúundermine bitcoin‚Äù.

The crypto companies that secured Epstein‚Äôs investment have grown into multibillion-dollar giants, especially Coinbase, which went public on the Nasdaq in 2021, and whose co-founder, Brian Armstrong, has heavily influenced crypto regulation in the United States.

Epstein‚Äôs 2014 investment in Coinbase was brokered by the crypto evangelist Brock Pierce, a former child actor and a co-founder of Tether, the world‚Äôs largest issuer of stablecoins, a kind of cryptocurrency whose value is typically pegged to a national currency.

Documents published by the justice department reveal Fred Ehrsam, a co-founder of Coinbase who spearheaded its fundraise, liaised with Pierce about Epstein‚Äôs investment in the company and sought to meet with Epstein ‚Äúif convenient‚Äù. Additional filings suggest Epstein sold half of his shares to Pierce‚Äôs firm, Blockchain Capital, for $15m in 2018.

A spokeswoman for Coinbase declined to comment; Pierce did not respond to requests for comment.

Epstein‚Äôs financing of bitcoin‚Äôs development stemmed from his role as a donor to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT). Over the course of 20 years, MIT accepted more than $800,000 from Epstein, who also facilitated more than $7m in donations from other wealthy individuals.

In communications from 2015 between Joichi Ito, then director of MIT‚Äôs Media Lab, a tech-focused research institute, and Epstein, Ito wrote that Epstein‚Äôs ‚Äúgift funds‚Äù were used to ‚Äúunderwrite‚Äù the launch of the Digital Currency Initiative, an offshoot of the Lab tasked with researching and developing open-source crypto technologies; in the same email thread, Ito explained that the Lab‚Äôs role was to serve as the ‚Äúprincipal home and funding source‚Äù for bitcoin. The Digital Currency Initiative did not respond to requests for comment.

In 2014, Ito brokered Epstein‚Äôs investment in Blockstream, which builds bitcoin-focused tech solutions. Epstein made a $500,000 early-stage investment in the company through an investment fund he co-owned with Ito. Email communications reveal Blockstream‚Äôs co-founders, Adam Back and Austin Hill, were invited by Epstein to meet in St Thomas, close to Little Saint James, the private island Epstein owned.

On Twitter, Back claimed that Blockstream understood Epstein to be a ‚Äúlimited partner in Ito‚Äôs fund‚Äù, which later divested from Blockstream ‚Äúdue to a potential conflict of interest, and other concerns‚Äù ‚Äì meaning that ‚ÄúBlockstream has no direct nor indirect financial connection with Jeffrey Epstein, or his estate‚Äù.

In communications with an Italian investor, Epstein noted that he ‚Äúlike[d]‚Äù Back. Hill continued communicating with Epstein into 2017, checking in with his ‚Äúfriend‚Äù following a storm in the Caribbean. ‚ÄúJust checking that your Island is OK,‚Äù reads the email thread‚Äôs subject line. Representatives for Blockstream and Hill did not respond to requests for comment.

Luke Dashjr, an early contributor to bitcoin‚Äôs development as well as to Blockstream, has called for Adam Back to resign from his role as Blockstream‚Äôs CEO over ties to Epstein. In an interview with the Guardian, Dashjr said Epstein‚Äôs interest in bitcoin ‚Äì namely, his ‚Äúattempts to undermine‚Äù bitcoin‚Äôs network, early-stage companies, and developers ‚Äì was a sign that ‚Äúevil men often seek to destroy what is good‚Äù.

Charlotte Fang, the founder of Remilia, which makes NFTs and other crypto-based art, said ‚Äúonly unserious people might care‚Äù about Epstein‚Äôs investment in bitcoin and Coinbase; in the latter case, ‚Äúonly the financially unsophisticated‚Äù would assume that he had ‚Äúany degree of influence over the direction‚Äù of the exchange, as his seven-figure investment was a small part of Coinbase‚Äôs fundraise.

‚ÄúBitcoin is a decentralized technology that required no funding, and Epstein was evidently a skeptical investor, who got in later than I did, and exited earlier than he should have,‚Äù Fang said.

‚ÄúGenerally speaking, retail consumers will not change their habits‚Äù around crypto following this recent release of Epstein files, according to Kadan Stadelmann of Komodo, a crypto platform. Investor practices, including their dependence on connections to cut checks, will probably adhere to the status quo, he added. Some competitor crypto exchanges might see new customers who are leaving Coinbase following these new allegations, he hypothesized ‚Äì as long as these exchanges didn‚Äôt take money from ‚Äúsimilar unsavory sources‚Äù.

As to why Epstein was so interested in crypto, and in Coinbase specifically? ‚ÄúEpstein might have liked Coinbase‚Äôs IPO prospects,‚Äù he surmised.

Cryptocurrencies‚Äô technological capabilities may have also played a role in Epstein‚Äôs interest in the sector, said Antulio Rosales, a professor at York University who studies crypto.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs his possibility of seeing markets without any ethical commitments, and without any pressures of social norms and of the law itself,‚Äù he said.

title: How a decades-old video game has helped me defeat the doomscroll
description:
Trading social media for Pok√©mon battles and evolutions in Kanto on a Game Boy Advance has been surprisingly serene
Cutting back on doomscrolling must be one of the hardest new year resolutions to keep. Instinctively tapping on the usual suspects on your phone‚Äôs home screen becomes a reflex, and vast quantities of money and user data have been specifically employed to keep you reaching for the phone, ingraining it into our work, leisure and social lives. You‚Äôll get no shame from me if you love your phone and have a healthy relationship with your apps, but I‚Äôve found myself struggling lately.
This year, I‚Äôm attempting to cut back on screen time ‚Äì sort of. I‚Äôm replacing the sleek oblong of my smartphone with something a little more fuzzy and nostalgic.
fullText:
Trading social media for Pok√©mon battles and evolutions in Kanto on a Game Boy Advance has been surprisingly serene

Cutting back on doomscrolling must be one of the hardest new year resolutions to keep. Instinctively tapping on the usual suspects on your phone‚Äôs home screen becomes a reflex, and vast quantities of money and user data have been specifically employed to keep you reaching for the phone, ingraining it into our work, leisure and social lives. You‚Äôll get no shame from me if you love your phone and have a healthy relationship with your apps, but I‚Äôve found myself struggling lately.

This year, I‚Äôm attempting to cut back on screen time ‚Äì sort of. I‚Äôm replacing the sleek oblong of my smartphone with something a little more fuzzy and nostalgic. In an attempt to dismantle my bad habit, I‚Äôm closing the feeds of instant updates and instead carrying around a Game Boy Advance. I‚Äôve been playing Pok√©mon FireRed, a remake of the very first Pok√©mon games, which turn 30 this month. Even this refreshed version is more than two decades old.

Improving your digital wellbeing doesn‚Äôt necessarily mean cutting out screen time completely. Not all screens are created equal. I‚Äôm hoping that swapping one screen for another isn‚Äôt like Indiana Jones switching out the golden idol with a big bag of sand, only for the booby trap boulder to crush me all the same.

I‚Äôd not played Pok√©mon regularly since 2006‚Äôs Pok√©mon Diamond on the Nintendo DS, which was my introduction to the franchise. I dabbled in Pok√©mon Black on the DS and Pok√©mon Legends: Arceus on the Nintendo Switch, but neither stuck. I‚Äôd convinced myself that once you‚Äôve played through one Pok√©mon game, you‚Äôve pretty much played them all. But as Hollywood has profitably realised, 20 years is a long enough gap for something to feel fresh again.

My first steps in Pok√©mon were taken in the Sinnoh region, so the prospect of visiting the Kanto region from the first games and catching the original 151 Pok√©mon felt exciting to me. But I couldn‚Äôt bring myself to start playing the original Red or Blue on a chunky old Game Boy. I might be trying to embrace a more analogue existence, but gaming without colour is my line in the sand.

FireRed‚Äôs positive effects on my life arrived unexpectedly quickly. It only took a couple of hours of exploration and encounters with wild Pok√©mon to make me forget about my phone. It was sat right next to me, but it was no longer calling to me like Gollum‚Äôs ring. Usually my device would find its way into my hand during loading breaks and elaborate cutscenes on narrative-heavy and beautiful modern PlayStation games.

Perhaps there‚Äôs some magic in FireRed‚Äôs more freeform approach to story and less overstimulating retro graphics. Maybe those gaps left by implied details in the design and dialogue leave space for my imagination ‚Äì which my doomscrolling habit had nearly atrophied. The world of Pok√©mon is serene and charming, despite constant trainer battles and gruelling gym leader face-offs, and even those are quite low stakes. A gaming experience hasn‚Äôt offered me such tranquility since I first picked up Animal Crossing. Try as he might, even Tom Nook can‚Äôt patent escapism.

Curiously, this adventure, though fresh for me, feels nostalgic. I‚Äôve never played with a team solely made up of monsters from the original Pok√©dex, yet somehow I‚Äôm transported back to the late 90s when it seemed like the world was going Pok√©-mad. I even named my rival after one of my childhood best friends. All these years later, it‚Äôs so satisfying to finally, thoroughly embrace this canon.

Pok√©mon is hardly counterculture: it‚Äôs the most profitable video game franchise in history. Pok√©mon is gearing up for a 30th anniversary year with a McDonald‚Äôs Happy Meal promotion, a new theme park, a partnership with the Natural History Museum and a Uniqlo line among much else ‚Äì so, if anything, it feels more zeitgeisty and omnipresent than it has in years. And yet it does feel rebellious to pick up an old Game Boy instead of my phone. It‚Äôs somehow unruly to take myself offline, just for a bit, to just have fun with a retro game. I‚Äôm able to enjoy technology on my own terms: I‚Äôm not coerced into microtransactions, I‚Äôm not relying on the latest oh-so essential firmware update, I‚Äôm not endlessly instructed to like, comment, 

Filling the natural breaks in my day with an old video game has done me the world of good, even if it‚Äôs evolving my Psyduck while dinner is in the oven or taking down a gym leader while waiting for a package. My phone‚Äôs screen time is already down by three hours a week since beginning this adventure. In a small way, it‚Äôs helping me to stop comparing myself with others and begin to tackle some existential dread that doomscrolling seems to encourage. Playing Pok√©mon FireRed in 2026 is utterly nourishing, and wonderfully low stakes compared to a social media ecosystem where everything is trying to appear equally urgent and meaningful.

If you‚Äôre trying to combat overthinking, insecurity or exhaustion by committing to the herculean task of using your phone less, take a quick trip to the Kanto region ‚Äì or another resolutely offline game world.

Meet Summer Britcher, the U.S. luge star who was parodied in an SNL skit and has a bright yellow sled
description: She has a chance to make a name for herself.
fullText:
Meet Summer Britcher, the U.S. luge star who was parodied in an SNL skit and has a bright yellow sled originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

With the Winter Olympics coming up, Saturday Night Live chose to feature a few sports, and one of them was luge.

Very few SNL viewers would've known who the skit was depicting. But U.S. star Summer Britcher knew -- the fake character was meant to be her.

"(It was)¬†a tall, lean woman who just happened to be racing on a yellow sled, which isn‚Äôt exactly a common color in luge," wrote the Associated Press' Tim Reynolds. "Britcher is tall, lean and, you guessed it, races on a yellow sled. The everyday SNL viewer probably didn‚Äôt make the connection. Those who know Britcher got it almost immediately."

‚ÄúI thought it was so funny,‚Äù Britcher told the AP. ‚ÄúI had no idea it was coming. My boyfriend sent it to me and as I was watching it, just more and more of the details stood out. And I was like, ‚ÄòHey, hang on a second.‚Äô‚Äù

Britcher may be a lot more famous soon.

On Monday, she'll race for a medal in the luge.

MORE:¬†Amber Glenn has the most surprising interest at the Olympics

Britcher is a 31-year old U.S. luge star from Baltimore, Maryland.

She first competed at the Olympics in 2014.

Britcher hasn't medaled at the Olympics, but she has earned a bronze and a silver in the team relay at the world championships.

Growing up in luge, Britcher spent time training in Lake Placid.

She was a high school soccer and tennis player in Glen Rock, Pennsylvania, and she has worked her way up in the world of luge since then.

MORE:¬†Breezy Johnson won a gold medal for the U.S., and then she broke it

Britcher is the best U.S. women's luge competitor ever, on paper.

She has seven career singles race wins on the World Cup circuit. Nobody from the United States has ever had more.

And given she's facing the best when she races there, that gives Britcher a chance to compete for a podium spot in Italy, for sure.

title: Harry Redknapp tells Man United exactly why they should appoint Michael Carrick permanently
description: Former Tottenham Hotspur and West Ham United manager Harry Redknapp has called for Michael Carrick to be given the Manchester United head coach position on a permanent basis.Dream start to life at Uni...
fullText:
Former Tottenham Hotspur and West Ham United manager Harry Redknapp has called for Michael Carrick to be given the Manchester United head coach position on a permanent basis.

Carrick is enjoying a fairytale start to life as caretaker boss. United brought him in during December as a temporary replacement for Ruben Amorim, who was dismissed after 14 months in charge.

Carrick beat Ole Gunnar Solskjaer to the role and so far, he is proving to be a shrewd acquisition. He has taken charge of four Premier League games, winning all of them.

United have beaten Manchester City, Arsenal, Fulham and most recently Tottenham in that superb run. But Carrick‚Äôs impact extends well beyond the results, which currently have the Red Devils firmly within the frame to finish within the guaranteed Champions League places.

Almost overnight, he has brought in a front-foot, positive style of football that has the fans believing once more.

While opposition defences have struggled to contain United‚Äôs aggressive approach, debate persists over whether Carrick is the right long-term choice for the club.

The likes of Roy Keane and Gary Neville have argued that United should not go for Carrick ‚Äì a claim that was rubbished by Michael Owen.

Speaking after the 3-2 win over Tottenham, Rio Ferdinand explained that it is getting increasingly difficult to ignore Carrick for the role permanently.

Redknapp has now weighed in, urging United to give him the job.

Redknapp, who gace Carrick is senior debut at West Ham in 1999, said [as quoted by The National], ‚ÄúI saw him when he was a 12-year-old at West Ham.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe used to come down from Newcastle during the school holidays. He‚Äôs just the nicest guy, fantastic footballer, class player, passed the ball, read the game, and I‚Äôm just so happy that he‚Äôs got a chance.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt have to keep bringing in second-rate foreign managers to England. There‚Äôs enough lads there. Give them the opportunity to do the job.‚Äù

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs lads in the lower divisions. Give them an opportunity.‚Äù

Redknapp added, ‚ÄúMichael‚Äôs got a chance now, so I‚Äôm pulling every week for him to keep getting results and get that job on a full-time basis.‚Äù

United are next in action on Tuesday when they go away to West Ham.

Featured image Carl Recine via Getty Images

The Peoples Person has been one of the world‚Äôs leading Man United news sites for over a decade. bsky.social

title: Los Angeles Lakers players who led NBA in scoring
description: Throughout NBA history, the Los Angeles Lakers have been home to some of the most dominant scorers the game has ever seen. From the league‚Äôs earliest days to the modern era, Lakers stars have not only carried their team offensively‚Ä¶
fullText:
Throughout NBA history, the Los Angeles Lakers have been home to some of the most dominant scorers the game has ever seen. From the league‚Äôs earliest days to the modern era, Lakers stars have not only carried their team offensively but also set the scoring standard for the entire NBA. Leading the league in scoring while wearing purple and gold has always signaled a season of individual brilliance and historical significance.

2025‚Äì26: 33.5 PPG (current pace)

In his first season wearing a Lakers uniform, Doncic immediately established himself as the league‚Äôs most dominant offensive force. His scoring lead reflects a rare blend of volume, efficiency, and creativity, as he punishes defenses at all three levels. Luka‚Äôs ability to control tempo while still producing elite numbers makes this season feel both historic and sustainable. If the pace holds, it would be one of the most impressive scoring campaigns in franchise history.

Kobe‚Äôs back-to-back scoring titles represent the apex of his individual offensive dominance. The 2004‚Äì05 season showcased his unmatched shot-making and willingness to shoulder the entire offensive burden. In 2005‚Äì06, he followed it up with another scoring crown, highlighted by legendary performances and relentless competitiveness. These seasons cemented Bryant as the most feared scorer of his era.

Shaq‚Äôs scoring title came during the lockout-shortened season, where his physical dominance was simply overwhelming. Defenses had no answer for his combination of size, power, and touch around the rim. Night after night, opponents were forced to foul or concede easy points. This season set the stage for the Lakers‚Äô upcoming dynasty.

Jerry West led the league in scoring during a period defined by tough defense and limited spacing, making his numbers even more remarkable. His offensive game was built on precision, footwork, and an unshakable confidence in big moments. West carried the Lakers with consistency and poise, embodying the prototype of a complete guard. This season further solidified his legacy as one of the greatest scorers of his generation.

George Mikan was the NBA‚Äôs first true dominant scorer and the foundation of the Lakers‚Äô early success. His three consecutive scoring titles came at a time when the league was still defining itself, and Mikan was clearly ahead of his peers. He forced rule changes, reshaped defensive strategies, and established the center position as the game‚Äôs focal point. These seasons made him the original face of Lakers greatness.

Each Lakers player who led the NBA in scoring reflects a different era, style, and evolution of the game, yet all share the same impact: offensive supremacy. Whether through finesse, power, or relentless shot-making, these seasons stand as benchmarks of greatness within the franchise‚Äôs storied legacy. Together, they reinforce why the Lakers remain synonymous with elite scorers and unforgettable individual performances.

The post Los Angeles Lakers players who led NBA in scoring appeared first on The Big Lead.

title: Alexandra Eala reaches career-best ranking as Emma Raducanu also climbs sharply
description: Alexandra Eala is in line for another boost after her performance at the Abu Dhabi Open. Her popularity was clear in Abu Dhabi, where plenty of supporters turned up just to watch her play.
fullText:
Alexandra Eala is in line for another boost after her performance at the Abu Dhabi Open.

Her popularity was clear in Abu Dhabi, where plenty of supporters turned up just to watch her play.

Eala‚Äôs tennis seems to be benefiting from this, with her enjoying a breakthrough season in 2025.

She hit a ranking milestone after the Australian Open and has now improved on that again by making it to the quarterfinals in Abu Dhabi.

Although she achieved a career-best ranking after the Australian Open, it is worth noting that Eala exited in the first round of the tournament.

She has since made back-to-back quarterfinal appearances, first at her home WTA 125 event in Manila and then at the WTA 500 tournament in Abu Dhabi.

That run in Abu Dhabi almost did not happen. Eala was down 4-0 and facing match point in the final set against Aliaksandra Sasnovich before pulling off a remarkable comeback.

Following that win, she moved up five spots in the rankings to reach world number 40, marking another milestone.

Aiming to continue her progress towards that goal, Eala is set to debut at the Qatar Open. Her first-round match will be against the promising Czech teenager, Tereza Valentova.

The 20-year-old star is now just eight places shy of being seeded at Grand Slams and some of the larger WTA 1000 events.

She is not the only player making moves this week. The biggest jump belongs to Sara Bejlek, who claimed her first WTA title by defeating Ekaterina Alexandrova and has soared 63 places to world number 38.

While she has not set a new career-best ranking, it has still been an encouraging week for Emma Raducanu.

The Briton reached her first final since winning the US Open, making it through to the title match at the WTA 250 event in Cluj-Napoca.

This time though, she fell short of the trophy, losing out to Sorana Cirstea in straight sets.

Even without the title, Raducanu‚Äôs run has seen her climb five spots in the rankings. She now sits at world number 24, her highest position since August 2022.

Next up for Raducanu is a first-round match against Camila Osorio at the Qatar Open, where she will look to continue her strong form.

Similar to Eala, the 23-year-old Briton will need to reduce the pressure of defending a large number of ranking points at the upcoming Miami Open before the tournament takes place next month.

title: What time does Jutta Leerdam actually race? Here‚Äôs the full order for Olympic women‚Äôs 1000-meter speed skating schedule today for Jake Paul's girlfriend
description: The Netherlands star is going for it.
fullText:
What time does Jutta Leerdam actually race? Here‚Äôs the full order for Olympic women‚Äôs 1000-meter speed skating schedule today for Jake Paul's girlfriend originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

Jutta Leerdam was so close at the 2022 Winter Olympics. In that competition, the Netherlands speed skating superstar won the silver medal in the 1000 meters.

On Monday in Italy, she goes for the final step up the podium. Jake Paul's fiancee, who has 5.1 million followers on Instagram, will be on the ice to race for the gold.

There are 30 competitors alive to race for the medals, and they take to the track in pairs. That means there are essentially 15 mini-races as part of the action.

The racing begins at 11:30 a.m. ET (5:30 p.m. local in Italy), but Leerdam won't be out there right away.

WATCH:¬†Women's downhill LIVE on Peacock

Jutta Leerdam is in the last of the 15 pairings in the 1000-meter speed skating.

Based on race time plus preparation for the next race, each pairing should take at least two minutes (maybe more).

If we used two minutes as the estimate, it'll be about half an hour into the competition that Leerdam takes the ice, which gets to about 12 noon ET.

Any types of delays will take it later, though, so don't be surprised if it's closer to 12:15-12:30 p.m. ET before Leerdam races for the gold medal.

Here's the order of 15 mini-races, which is generally from slowest expected times to fastest:

Vigl, Italy; Schulting, Netherlands

Han, China; Morozova, Kazakhstan

Smeding, Great Britain; Lee, Korea

Jackson and Bowe should each take the track less than 15 minutes before Leerdam.

title: Zak Brown says Red Bull surprised him at Barcelona F1 2026 shakedown test
description: After watching the early running at Barcelona, McLaren CEO Zak Brown believes the same four teams will stay ahead of the pack under F1‚Äôs 2026 regulations. Formula 1 has entered a new era in 2026 with the introduction of new engine, aero, chassis and tyre rules.
fullText:
After watching the early running at Barcelona, McLaren CEO Zak Brown believes the same four teams will stay ahead of the pack under F1‚Äôs 2026 regulations.

Formula 1 has entered a new era in 2026 with the introduction of new engine, aero, chassis and tyre rules. The 2026 F1 regulations mark the biggest regulatory overhaul in history, due largely to the new engines with a near 50/50 split between electric and combustion power.

The sweeping changes led some to wonder if they might shake up the competitive order, but after early testing in Barcelona, it seems little has changed at the front. McLaren still look like Mercedes‚Äô main challenger for now.

Mercedes were already expected by many to lead under these regulations, especially with their history of excelling during rule changes. There are even suggestions they may have exploited a grey area within F1‚Äôs new power unit guidelines.

There were questions around Red Bull heading into the 2026 season, with the team taking on engine manufacturing for the first time. It was Christian Horner who set up Red Bull Powertrains when Honda signalled their exit from Formula 1.

Despite early doubts about how reliable that first RBPT DM01 unit would be, built in collaboration with Ford, McLaren CEO Zak Brown came away from Barcelona ‚Äúimpressed‚Äù by how solid it looked right out of the box. Brown even admitted he‚Äôd prefer if it wasn‚Äôt as competitive as it appeared.

‚ÄúIt kind of looks like the usual suspects, but it is hard to tell in what order,‚Äù said Brown, speaking via RacingNews365. ‚ÄúThe Red Bull engine was very strong.

‚ÄúI think everyone was pleasantly surprised. I‚Äôd rather them not be as competitive, but I‚Äôm impressed with what they‚Äôve done because they came out, they did a lot of miles and they seem to be very competitive.‚Äù

Red Bull are still working on the drivability of their 2026 F1 rules engine following the test in Barcelona, where reliability was the top concern for every team. But the early signs suggest Red Bull will be among the front-running teams with McLaren, Mercedes and Ferrari again.

The quartet were the class of the field during the 2025 F1 season, with McLaren securing 34 podiums, Red Bull taking 15, Mercedes reaching 12 and Ferrari getting seven from a possible 72. The remaining four rostrums went the way of Williams (2), Sauber and Racing Bulls (1).

McLaren (14), Red Bull (8) and Mercedes (2) even accounted for all 24 Grand Prix wins in the final year of F1‚Äôs latest ground-effect era. Also, McLaren won the 2025 F1 constructors‚Äô title at the Singapore Grand Prix with six rounds to spare, to match Red Bull‚Äôs record set in 2023.

The Woking natives ultimately finished last year with a 364-point lead over Mercedes in the constructors‚Äô standings, as Lando Norris also won the F1 drivers‚Äô championship for the first time. Red Bull and Ferrari were third and fourth with 382 and 435-point deficits to McLaren.

title: Why Eileen Gu competes for China in skiing at Olympics and not U.S. after controversy
description: Here's what you need to know.
fullText:
Why Eileen Gu competes for China in skiing at Olympics and not U.S. after controversy originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

One of the most well-known athletes at the 2026 Winter Olympics is a ski star competing for China.

Eileen Gu, though, wasn't born in China. She was born in the United States. It draws extra attention to her moves on the slopes, including during Monday's slopestyle competition.

Her worldwide popularity due to her early fame and social media stardom only shines an additional light on her every move.

Gu got her Olympics competition underway Saturday in Italy when she finished second in the qualifying round of the women's slopestyle competition.

She'll have plenty more time in the spotlight before these Olympics are through.

MORE:¬†Amber Glenn has the most surprising interest at the Olympics

Gu made her decision to compete for China when she was 15 years old in 2022, and she did it for representation reasons.

‚ÄúThe U.S. already has the representation,‚Äù Gu has said in the past about popularity of women's skiiers in the United States. ‚ÄúI like building my own pond.‚Äù

Adding a bit to the controversy was that Gu had already competed for Team USA during three slopestyle World Cup events before she made the switch.

She wrote at the time that it was a "once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to help to promote the sport I love."

MORE:¬†Breezy Johnson won a gold medal for the U.S., and then she broke it

Gu then captured all the headlines while landing a double cork 1620 in the big air competition to claim the gold medal.

‚ÄúMy whole thing was, it‚Äôs all upside,‚Äù recalls Gu. ‚ÄúBecause if I land, I will win the Olympics. If I don‚Äôt land, then I get to make history as the first person to ever try this trick in such a situation. It‚Äôs a decision that I would be super proud of and live with forever.‚Äù

She'll be trying to add more medals to her collection at these Olympics. And she'll have plenty of people watching.

title: NBA 2026 Three-point contest participants
description: The 2026 NBA Three-Point Contest brings together a compelling mix of proven champions, first-time participants, and rising shooters who reflect how central the long ball has become in today‚Äôs game. From seasoned All-Stars with past hardware to young players eager‚Ä¶
fullText:
The 2026 NBA Three-Point Contest brings together a compelling mix of proven champions, first-time participants, and rising shooters who reflect how central the long ball has become in today‚Äôs game. From seasoned All-Stars with past hardware to young players eager to announce themselves on a national stage, this field is stacked with both credibility and intrigue. Each competitor enters with a distinct shooting profile, ensuring a contest defined by contrasting styles, streaks, and momentum swings.

Devin Booker returns to the Three-Point Contest as one of the more experienced shooters in the field, bringing back memorable performances from past All-Star Weekends. Although his current 3-point percentage this season is a career low, his pedigree and confidence with the deep ball keep him a threat on the racks. Booker won this event in 2018 and has made multiple appearances, which gives him both historical relevance and fan appeal. Expect him to lean on his rhythm and composure when the clock starts.

Rookie Kon Knueppel has quickly established himself as one of the league‚Äôs rising long-range threats with an excellent percentage this season. His inclusion in the contest marks a rare opportunity for a first-year player to compete for the title, and he‚Äôll aim to become the first rookie ever to win. Knueppel‚Äôs high volume and efficient shooting make him a serious contender right out of the gate. His youth and fearless shooting style will be fun to watch as he battles veterans.

Despite missing the entire NBA season with a torn Achilles, Damian Lillard will still suit up for the 3-Point Contest, a testament to his elite reputation as a marksman. Lillard is a two-time winner of this event and can tie the all-time record with his third title. His career 3-point scoring and clutch gene make him a perennial fan favorite, regardless of in-season play. Lillard‚Äôs participation adds a compelling storyline of resilience and competitive pride.

Tyrese Maxey enters the contest riding a breakout season as one of the NBA‚Äôs most dynamic scorers, combining pace with deep shooting prowess. This will be his first appearance in the Three-Point Contest, aligning with his first All-Star starter nod. Maxey‚Äôs ability to make tough catch-and-shoot attempts under pressure gives him a versatile edge on the racks. His confidence from downtown blends well with his overall offensive game, making him a dark-horse candidate.

Donovan Mitchell is another All-Star entering the contest with a reputation for confident and flashy deep shooting. As the Cavaliers‚Äô lead scorer, Mitchell blends volume with creativity, often pulling up from range in rhythm. His presence adds star power and competitive intensity to the field, especially when the spotlight gets bright. Expect Mitchell to attack the money balls with the same aggression he brings in late-game situations.

Jamal Murray brings his sharpshooting pedigree from both the regular season and playoff stages to the Three-Point Contest. Known for his calm demeanor and clutch threes, Murray complements Stephen Curry‚Äôs shooting leadership in Denver‚Äôs offense. This appearance aligns with his first All-Star selection, showcasing his ascent among the league‚Äôs premier perimeter scorers. Given his range and confidence, he can heat up quickly when the rack lights turn on.

Veteran forward Bobby Portis Jr. earned his first 3-Point Contest nod thanks to a breakout shooting season, boasting one of the highest percentages among contestants. His stride into elite floor spacing has helped Milwaukee‚Äôs offense evolve, making him more than a traditional big man. Portis‚Äô smooth release and catch-and-shoot rhythm make him a legitimate threat in this format. His inclusion underscores how modern bigs can impact spacing and contest formats alike.

Norman Powell enters the event as an All-Star and one of Miami‚Äôs most reliable 3-point shooters this season. His shooting profile blends athleticism with catch-and-shoot efficiency, and he has experience from prior contests as well. Powell‚Äôs ability to get hot in spurts could make him dangerous in the rapid-fire rhythm of the 3-Point Contest. As a player who thrives in momentum, he‚Äôll look to heat up early and carry it through the rounds.

When the final rack is emptied on Saturday, February 14 at 5:00 p.m. ET, the 2026 Three‚ÄëPoint Contest is sure to hinge on rhythm, confidence, and a competitor‚Äôs ability to perform under the clock. With this blend of elite scorers, specialists, and fearless newcomers all taking aim at the same moment, the difference between victory and elimination could be a single swish or miss. No matter who hoists the title at the State Farm 3‚ÄëPoint Contest, this field underscores how deep shooting continues to define the modern NBA and why this event remains one of All‚ÄëStar Weekend‚Äôs most anticipated traditions.

title: Updated look at Bears' pending free agents for 2026
description: With the 2026 offseason in full swing, here's a breakdown of the Bears players who are slated to hit free agency next month.
fullText:
The 2025 NFL season has concluded with Super Bowl LX, and now the focus shifts to the 2026 offseason. For the Chicago Bears, they'll be looking to shore up the roster for head coach Ben Johnson in free agency and the 2026 NFL Draft.

The Bears have some important roster moves to make this offseason, including with some in-house free agents -- whether that's re-signing some or filling holes left by departing players. Chicago has 27 players scheduled to become free agents in 2026 according to¬†Over The Cap, including some key starters and contributors.

There are some players who could very well sign a contract extension, including safeties Kevin Byard and Jaquan Brisker, as well as cornerback Nahshon Wright and linebacker D'Marco Jackson, who all had big seasons with the Bears. But there are some big decisions to be made by general manager Ryan Poles about those players and the rest of the group of pending free agents.

Here's a look at the Bears players set to hit the open market in free agency:

The 2026 free agency negotiation window begins March 9, where teams can negotiate with available players. The free agency period officially opens two days later on March 11.

The Bears are projected to be $5.3 million over the salary cap for the 2026 season, which is the 12th worst in the league. But Chicago will make some moves in regards to contract restructures and perhaps parting ways with some expensive veterans to free up cap space to make some moves this offseason.

title: Where LSU women's basketball stands in updated NET rankings
description: LSU women's basketball won in dominant fashion on Sunday. Where do Kim Mulkey's Tigers rank in the latest NET rankings?
fullText:
After a win on Sunday, LSU women's basketball is holding firm in the top five of the NCAA's latest NET rankings, a key factor the NCAA selection committee looks at when seeding teams in March.

LSU is sitting just behind two SEC rivals, with South Carolina ranking No. 3 and Texas sitting at No. 4. LSU is 22-3 on the year and 4-3 in games vs. quad one opponents, meaning all of their losses have been to Q1 teams. LSU is 3-0 vs. quad two opponents and 3-0 vs. quad three opponents.

LSU beat Auburn 77-44 on Sunday, bouncing back after the Tigers fell at Texas last week. Freshman ZaKiyah Johnson led the way for LSU with 16 points. MiKaylah Williams also scored in double-digits.

LSU's net ranking indicates the Tigers are still in play for a No. 1 seed in the NCAA Tournament. March is approaching, but the Tigers still have several chances to build their resume while already having a few signature wins under their belt.

LSU's next game is a big one as the Tigers will host South Carolina in Baton Rouge on Saturday. LSU has all week to prepare as they search for an elusive victory over Dawn Staley's Gamecocks.

title: The Sporting News national high school girls basketball top 25 rankings (Feb. 9)
description: Bullis is up to No. 17 with a full head of steam after upsetting Long Island Lutheran.
fullText:
The Sporting News national high school girls basketball top 25 rankings (Feb. 9) originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

It's finally high school basketball postseason time in a small but hardy handful of high-powered states and federations. And despite Bullis' ESPN-televised upset of Long Island Lutheran, the rankings have more or less stabilized ‚Äì for now.

Here are The Sporting News national high school girls basketball rankings for the week of Feb. 9.

PREVIOUS RANKINGS:¬†Preseason¬†|¬†Dec. 1¬†|¬†Dec. 8¬†|¬†Dec. 15¬†|¬†Dec. 22¬†|¬†Dec. 29¬†|¬†Jan. 5¬†|¬†Jan. 12¬†|¬†Jan.¬†19¬†|¬†Jan. 26¬†| Feb. 2

After winning a disputed national title last season, Bishop McNamara is drawing nearer to a second consecutive national title ‚Äì perhaps an undisputed one ‚Äì with every week in which it wins out. Last week, the Mustangs pulled through¬†in overtime against Elizabeth Seton for the second time this season and then beat St. John's by a 14-point margin. Only TAHC, St. Mary's Ryken, and Bishop Ireton remain on their regular season schedule, and Bishop Ireton also took the Mustangs to overtime earlier this season.

The Knights beat Rancho Christian 85-65 in a tuneup game to end the regular season. Ontario Christian is the No. 1 seed in the CIF-Southern Section Open Division playoffs as expected and shares a pool with Rancho Christian and JSerra ‚Äì two teams it's already beaten by 20 points this season.

Mercifully, the Cavaliers' regular season is down to its last week after a 70-37 rout of Green Run and 88-13 demolition of Ocean Lakes. Princess Anne's 70-57 win over Bullis looks even better now after Bullis upset Long Island Lutheran.

The Monarchs cruised past St. Ignatius 66-22 in their only game of the week.

Long Island Lutheran's upset loss to Bullis doesn't help the Trailblazers' stock in a vacuum due to their loss against Long Island Lutheran, but the Trailblazers actually move up a spot without any teams having a strong argument to leap them. Like Ontario Christian, Sierra Canyon enters CIF-SS Open Division pool play tasked with beating two teams it's already beaten ‚Äì Oak Park and Corona Centennial, the latter of which played the Trailblazers to a 62-55 finish.

The winning streak is up to 11 games, and all except for the win over Long Island Lutheran have been blowouts.

It's no surprise to see Bullis breaking through for a high-ranking victory, and the blow is cushioned by the fact that LuHi is still 1-1 this season against Bullis. But it's definitely concerning to see the Crusaders fall 75-72 to a team they previously beat 70-49.

Unsurprisingly, Etiwanda didn't lose another game for the rest of the regular season after frontcourt stars Jaylee Moore and Tess Oldenburg became eligible on Dec. 26 following the CIF's transfer sit-out period. The two-time reigning national champions and three-time reigning Open Division state champions crack the top eight for the first time this season and have a serious shot to continue to their dynastic postseason success across the Southern Section and/or state playoffs. Etiwanda will face Fairmont Prep and Saint Joseph (Lakewood) in CIF-SS pool play after beating Saint Joseph 72-44 in January.

The Dragons made a statement with a 65-38 rout of West Des Moines Valley to nearly clinch a third consecutive undefeated regular season.

The Moose' regular season is complete and they will play for an FSL title this week.

It's unclear what the rest of SPIRE's season looks like, but we can probably all agree that it would be fun to see them in a national postseason setting.

St. James stayed sharp with a 77-52 rout of St. Frances Academy.

A bye week came immediately after DME Academy's only week of the season. DME has the resume to bounce back up in the rankings if the opportunities arise with its only loss coming to The St. James Performance Academy.

The Lancers blew out St. Rose, Red Bank Regional, and Thrive Carter to keep the winning streak going.

Red Bank Catholic's defense was stifling as the Caseys pulled out a win in their lowest-scoring game of the season, a 41-33 victory over formidable Cardinal O'Hara.

Despite a 14-point loss to top-ranked Bishop McNamara, St. John's moved up four spots thanks to its prior win over Bullis, which just beat Long Island Lutheran. The Cadets also won by 20 points last week against an Elizabeth Seton team that pushed them to overtime earlier this season and has now done so twice against Bishop McNamara too.

Ivanna Wilson-Manyacka went off for 26 points and 15 rebounds as Bullis toppled Long Island Lutheran on ESPN. For now, the Bulldogs rise four spots for the win over Long Island Lutheran, which dropped three. If that win didn't "only" move them to 1-1 on the season against LuHi, it might've vaulted them a bit higher despite their loss to St. John's. But Bullis' current winning streak could definitely continue to move the needle in the rankings as Bullis' season winds on. And avenging a 21-point loss to an elite team is an excellent sign and accomplishment.

LPA only scored half as many points against Kingdom Collegiate Academy as it did when it beat KCA 88-72 in January, losing 53-44 in its only game of the week.

The Timberwolves passed a key test on Tuesday by beating West Linn 61-52.

One more game and the undefeated regular season is official. Will anybody beat Westlake at all this season?

The blurb for Westlake can be copy/pasted for Texas' other undefeated large school powerhouse. With Westlake in UIL Division 6A and Wagner in 5A, both could go undefeated through state titles ‚Äì although both will have to outlast deep playoff fields of serious unranked competition to do so.

The Tigers look to beat Wayne Memorial, which is otherwise unbeaten, for the second time this season on Tuesday. Belleville won 77-49 when they played on Jan. 16.

Hoover finished the regular season in strong fashion, putting on for Alabama as usual in a 75-51 win over perennial Georgia stalwart Holy Innocents' Episcopal. At this point, the Buccaneers are a heavy favorite to otherwise win out after getting upset in their season debut.

It's a juicy CIF-SS Open Division pool play pairing for Sage Hill, which got placed in a bracket with Redondo Union and Mater Dei. Sage Hill has given Mater Dei a run for its money a handful of times in recent memory but hasn't broken through, and this will be its best chance yet.

With four games left in the regular season, Wauwatosa East is in the clear having previously blown out every team remaining on its schedule. The Red Raiders and Arrowhead are both in WIAA Division 1, so a playoff rematch is incoming if both teams remain unbeaten against all other challengers.

fullText:
It's the end of Habib Beye's reign at Rennes. According to information from RMC Sport, the coach has reportedly been relieved of his duties by the management of Stade Rennais.

After a more than complicated start to the season, the Breton club managed to steady the ship, only to experience a sharp decline in results since the beginning of the year.

The series of four consecutive defeats against Lorient (0-2), Monaco (4-0), Marseille (3-0), and Lens (3-1) proved costly for the former Senegalese international.

It remains to be seen who will succeed him. A few days ago, Franck Haise was reported to be close to Stade Rennais by L'√âquipe. Currently sixth in Ligue 1, Rennes can still hope to secure a European spot by the end of the season.

title: NFL Free Agency: 9 Eagles players who seem likely to depart
description: With the off-season officially underway in Philadelphia, we're looking at nine players who seem likely to depart.
fullText:
The 2025 season is complete after a thrilling Super Bowl. Now the work begins for all 32 teams to retool their roster and prepare for a potential playoff appearance next season. After an offensive coordinator and passing game coordinator change, the Eagles' roster will likely undergo further changes. The Birds have 21 players who'll test the restricted or unrestricted free-agent market during the 2026 NFL offseason. Several key factors include a pending contract extension for Jalen Carter and the contract status for star tight end Dallas Goedert.

Reed Blankenship is one of the biggest names on the list, and the defense could look drastically different with Nakobe Dean entering the final year of his rookie deal.

With the off-season officially underway in Philadelphia, we're looking at nine players who seem likely to depart.

The 27-year-old Uche played in 12 games and recorded 1 sack.

Ojulari saw action in three games before spending the bulk of the season on IR.

The 2022 sixth-round pick just finished his fourth season in the NFL, and likely played his last game in Philadelphia. A Former college teammate of Jalen Hurts at Oklahoma, eaching the end of his rookie contract. Calcaterra played in 62 games with 22 starts.

A former Commanders first-round pick, Dotson spent two unproductive seasons with the Eagles, playing in 34 games and recording 37 catches on 69 targets for 478 yards and one regular-season touchdown.

A versatile and solid lineman, the 29-year-old played 363 snaps at center and guard, allowing two sacks.

The Eagles acquired Howell via trade in August, making him the third-string quarterback. He didn't play a single game with the Eagles this season, but could certainly return.

Okoronkwo played in just one game this season and landed on IR.

Dillon signed a one-year deal with Philadelphia after missing last season with a neck injury, but things didn't work out. The veteran running back lost his role when the Eagles brought in Tank Bigsby via trade. Dillon, 27, ended up with just 12 rushing attempts for 60 yards this season.

The Eagles signed Epps to their practice squad at the start of the season and eventually promoted him to the active roster. When rookie Drew Mukuba fractured his ankle, Epps regained his starting role at safety next to Blankenship.

The 30-year-old veteran signed a one-year deal with the Eagles in the offseason and improved for Vic Fangio as the season went on, outplaying Kelee Ringo and Jakorian Bennett.

This article originally appeared on Eagles Wire: NFL Free Agency: 9 Eagles players who seem likely to depart

title: MVG eyeing public transport options for Bayern Munich vs. RB Leipzig
description: How will fans get the the game between FC Bayern and RB Leipzig?
fullText:
As Bayern Munich prepares to face RB Leipzig in the DFB-Pokal quarterfinals on Wednesday, there is uncertainty about just how fans will be able to get to the Allianz Arena.

The Munich Transport Company (MVG) is in the midst of labor strife and might not support the normal runs to the stadium on game day:

The Munich Transport Company (MVG) issued a statement today: ‚ÄúThe MVG will be on strike again on Wednesday, February 11 (..) How the Allianz Arena can be reached by public transport for the cup match on Wednesday evening is currently being intensively examined. MVG is in close contact with the Allianz Arena, FC Bayern, the authorities and other partners regarding this matter. Under the aforementioned circumstances, it does not appear possible to connect the stadium to a limited extent by bus. Whether and which specific options will be available on Wednesday evening is part of the ongoing review. As soon as reliable results are available, they will be communicated.‚Äù

This certainly complicates matters for fans who are attending the match. We will follow the situation and provide updates as things develop.

If you are looking for more Bayern Munich and German national team coverage, check out the latest episodes of Bavarian Podcast Works, which you can get on Acast, Spotify, Apple, or any leading podcast distributor‚Ä¶

title: Liam Rosenior signals readiness to cash in on ¬£35m star with Roberto De Zerbi watching
description: With the summer window approaching, Chelsea are expected to be active again under Todd Boehly and Clearlake, who spent nearly ¬£300m last summer. Despite the heavy spending, they balanced it with significant sales.
fullText:
With the summer window approaching, Chelsea are expected to be active again under Todd Boehly and Clearlake, who spent nearly ¬£300m last summer.

Despite the heavy spending, they balanced it with significant sales. Noni Madueke went to Arsenal for over ¬£50m and Christopher Nkunku made the move to Milan.

There are clear areas where Chelsea are looking to strengthen this time around. They need a new goalkeeper, have shown interest in defensive reinforcements, and cover in midfield is also on the list. Emmanuel Emegha has been brought in to add depth up front.

Jamie Gittens and Alejandro Garnacho have not found their feet at Stamford Bridge yet. If Geovany Quenda is not considered ready, the club may look for another winger. All signs point towards more changes ahead.

Among Chelsea‚Äôs current choices, Benoit Badiashile has slipped down the order, even before Levi Colwill returns to full fitness or Mamadou Sarr and Aaron Anselmino get their opportunities in the starting XI.

Right now, Badiashile looks to be behind Wesley Fofana, Trevoh Chalobah and Tosin Adarabioyo in Rosenior‚Äôs plans. By the time the summer arrives, there‚Äôs a good chance he‚Äôll be looking for a new club.

Caught Offside have noted that with Colwill, Sarr, Anselmino and potential new arrivals all competing for places, the ¬£35m centre-back is likely to struggle for any meaningful game time if he stays at Stamford Bridge next season.

According to Caught Offside, AC Milan are interested in adding another Chelsea player to a list that already includes Ruben Loftus-Cheek, Nkunku, Christian Pulisic and Fikayo Tomori. And they are not the only ones keeping an eye on him.

The report also suggests that Juventus might consider a summer move if he becomes available. Meanwhile, there is even talk of Roberto De Zerbi looking to bring the former Monaco defender back to France.

It is becoming increasingly clear that breaking into the first team will be a challenge for him. Rosenior has already shown a preference for Chalobah and Fofana as his main centre-backs, and Colwill has not even returned yet.

Badiashile needs to recognise the situation he is in ‚Äì there are too many players ahead of him, and staying put would likely mean limited minutes. A summer move looks like the best option if he wants regular football at this stage of his career.

title: Beanpot Preview: Boston College vs. boston university
description: Who: Boston College Eagles (15-9-1) vs boston university terriers (13-13-2) When: Monday, 2/9 Where:TD Garden, Boston, MA Puck Drop: 7:30PM How to Watch: The matchup will be live on NESN. terriers Preview: What to Watch For:
fullText:
Who: Boston College Eagles (15-9-1) vs boston university terriers (13-13-2)

How to Watch: The matchup will be live on NESN.

It hasn‚Äôt been that long since the Eagles met the terriers; the Eagles came away with the 4-1 win at Agganis a week and some ago, and Louka Cloutier & Dean Letourneau were named second and first stars of the night respectively.

Cole Hutson still leads the terriers with 25 points, followed by Cole Eiserman who has 17.

In net, Yegorov has a .902 save percentage.

The terriers won against Northeastern in a shootout last Monday night to punch their ticket to the championship game. They beat Maine in OT on Friday in their in-between game.

Honestly, I don‚Äôt know. The Eagles simply laid an egg on Friday night against Vermont, getting blown out on home ice 6-1 and taking a big hit to their NPI.

The team was clearly distracted, and no one had a good game. There‚Äôs not really much to take away from it or much more I can say. It was a lackluster, uninspiring effort for a game that required them to stay focused and needed to end with them feeling confident. This is when you hope someone is able to rally the group with a short turnaround and remind them what they‚Äôre capable of ‚Äì whether that‚Äôs the coaches or the captains or an unsung leader without a letter.

There‚Äôs a lot of noise surrounding the Eagles after their performance against Vermont, despite their strong showing against Harvard ‚Äì they‚Äôre going to have to completely block it out and get back on track.

title: Klint Kubiak confirms Seattle Seahawks future immediately after winning Super Bowl LX
description: Klint Kubiak addressed his future within minutes of the Seattle Seahawks winning Super Bowl LX, offering clarity that quickly shifted attention away from the celebration. The offensive coordinator spoke candidly on the field, acknowledging both the magnitude of the moment and what comes next in his coaching career.
fullText:
Klint Kubiak addressed his future within minutes of the Seattle Seahawks winning Super Bowl LX, offering clarity that quickly shifted attention away from the celebration.

The offensive coordinator spoke candidly on the field, acknowledging both the magnitude of the moment and what comes next in his coaching career.

Speaking to NFL Network moments after the final whistle, Klint Kubiak reflected on the win while hinting at an imminent transition.

‚ÄúYeah! That‚Äôs up to God, and we‚Äôre just gonna we‚Äôre gonna enjoy tonight. You guys know I‚Äôm going to Las Vegas. I‚Äôm fired up about it. But tonight, for one more night,‚Äù the Seahawks OC said.

The comments immediately drew attention because they acknowledged what had already been widely expected. Kubiak is set to become the new head coach of the Las Vegas Raiders, bringing his Super Bowl-winning credibility with him.

Rather than deflecting the question, Kubiak leaned into the reality of the situation. He made it clear that while his focus remained on celebrating with the Seahawks, his next chapter was already in motion.

The conversation turned more direct as Kubiak was pressed further on his future, with the coach offering unmistakable confirmation of his next step.

‚ÄúHell yeah, I‚Äôm going, of course. I‚Äôm going. Yeah, just confirmed it right here,‚Äù Kubiak added.

The remarks removed any remaining doubt about his departure from Seattle. After helping guide the Seahawks to a Super Bowl title, Kubiak is now preparing to take over a Raiders franchise looking for stability and identity.

The Raiders are handing him the keys at a time when the team is searching for long-term direction, while Kubiak arrives with momentum built from championship success.

For Seattle, the timing is bittersweet. The Seahawks secured Super Bowl glory, but the victory also marked the end of Kubiak‚Äôs tenure with the organization.

Eagle-eyed Olympics-watchers might notice something a little different with American skier Mikaela Shiffrin at these Milano Cortina Winter Games.

Nothing with her skiing, mind you.

But if the TV cameras try to get a little up close and personal while she's competing on the slopes of Cortina, you might see something missing.

As Shiffrin explains in an Instagram reel she apparently recorded from her hotel room in Italy, she recently "went a little bit too far" with her personal grooming. Now there's, in her words, "a high likelihood that I'm going to cross the finish line and I'll just have half an eyebrow."

Shiffrin's split-second decision-making on the slopes has helped make her one of the greatest skiers in history. But her spontaneous decision to shave part of her eyebrow may not have been one of her best.

title: Alabama shortstop named to Golden Spikes Award preseason watch list
description: Alabama shortstop Justin Lebron has been named to the preseason watch list for the 2026 Golden Spikes Award.
fullText:
Star Alabama shortstop Justin Lebron has officially been named to the 2026 Golden Spikes Award preseason watch list, which was unveiled by USA Baseball on Friday. Lebron was one of 55 total players named to the preseason watch list.

A returning starter, Lebron will more than likely play a crucial role in the Tide‚Äôs lineup throughout the 2026 season. The talented shortstop was nothing short of elite in 2025, as Lebron was credited with 18 home runs while batting an impressive .316 on the year. Lebron recorded 72 RBI in 2025 as well, as the star shortstop will look to pick up right where he left off.

Lebron started all 59 games for the Tide last season. The shortstop was named as a Golden Spikes Award semifinalist during his sophomore campaign, as Lebron was widely regarded as one of the top shortstops in all of college baseball in 2025.

Lebron and the Tide will begin the season on Feb. 13 against Washington State, as Alabama will look to start the 2026 campaign with a series win over the Cougars.
